t: Job 13
Job Continues: Still I Will Hope in God
“Behold,*pn my eye has seen all this, my*ld ear has heard and understood it.
What*ln you know, I also know; I*ld am not inferior to you.
But*ln I would speak to the Almighty, and*ld I desire to argue my case with God.
As*ln for you, you whitewash with lies; worthless*ld physicians are you all.
Oh*ln that you would keep silent, and*ld it would be your wisdom!
Hear*ln now my argument and*ld listen to the pleadings of my lips.
Will*ln you speak falsely for God and*ld speak deceitfully for him?
Will*ln you show partiality toward him? Will*ld you plead the case for God?
Will*ln it be well with you when he searches you out? Or*ld can you deceive him, as one deceives a man?
He*ln will surely rebuke you if*ld in secret you show partiality.
Will*ln not his majesty terrify you, and*ld the dread of him fall upon you?
Your*ln maxims are proverbs of ashes; your*ld defenses are defenses of clay.
“Let*pn me have silence, and I will speak, and*ld let come on me what may.
Why*ln should I take my flesh in my teeth and*ld put my life in my hand?
Though*ln he slay me, I will hope in him; yet*ld I will argue my ways to his face.
This*ln will be my salvation, that*ld the godless shall not come before him.
Keep*ln listening to my words, and*ld let my declaration be in your ears.
Behold,*ln I have prepared my case; I*ld know that I shall be in the right.
Who*ln is there who will contend with me? For*ld then I would be silent and die.
Only*ln grant me two things, then*ld I will not hide myself from your face:
withdraw*ln your hand far from me, and*ld let not dread of you terrify me.
Then*ln call, and I will answer; or*ld let me speak, and you reply to me.
How*ln many are my iniquities and my sins? Make*ld me know my transgression and my sin.
Why*ln do you hide your face and*ld count me as your enemy?
Will*ln you frighten a driven leaf and*ld pursue dry chaff?
For*ln you write bitter things against me and*ld make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
You*ln put my feet in the stocks and*ld watch all my paths; you*ld set a limit for the soles of my feet.
Man*ln wastes away like a rotten thing, like*ld a garment that is moth-eaten.
